SENT.plain: The effect of the opiate antagonist naloxone on both the neurological deficit and regional cortical blood flow after middle cerebral artery occlusion in the cat was investigated
In animals with mild symptoms, naloxone did not consistently produce a significant behavioral effect

In all cats with neurological deficits, including hemiplegia or severe hemiparesis, 2 mg/kg naloxone administered intravenously 4 h after the ischemic lesion produced a reversal of neurological symptoms
This effect began within 2 min following naloxone injection and lasted for approximately 20 min
Animals were then anesthetized and cortical blood flow was measured by the hydrogen clearance method
Average cortical blood flow on the side of the occlusion was 50% that of the control side
Naloxone produced a significant additional decrease of 19.5% in cortical blood flow in the ischemic hemisphere, whereas no effect on blood flow on the control side was noted

Thus, although naloxone appears to temporarily reverse the severe neurological deficits resulting from middle cerebral artery occlusion in the cat, this effect appears to be accompanied by a decrease in local blood flow to the ischemic cortex
